questions.text: Which muscle is supplied by the both tibial and common peroneal nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • Biceps femoris: The biceps femoris muscle is innervated by the tibial and common peroneal nerves. The tibial nerve supplies the long head of the biceps femoris, while the common peroneal nerve supplies the short head. Therefore, the tibial and common peroneal nerves do supply the biceps femoris muscle

Incorrect options:

Option A: Gracilis: The gracilis muscle is primarily innervated by the obturator nerve, not the tibial or common peroneal nerve. Therefore, the tibial and common peroneal nerves do not supply the gracilis muscle

Option C: Adductor longus: The adductor longus muscle is primarily innervated by the obturator nerve, not the tibial or common peroneal nerve. Thus, the tibial and common peroneal nerves do not supply the adductor longus muscle.

Option D: Adductor magnus: The adductor magnus muscle is primarily innervated by the obturator and sciatic nerves. The sciatic nerve, which is composed of the tibial and common peroneal nerves, supplies the posterior part of the adductor magnus. However, the tibial and common peroneal nerves alone do not supply the adductor magnus muscle.

questions.text: A muscle is attached to the area marked in the given Image. What is the action of this muscle on the hip joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Extension and lateral rotation

Explanation:

  • The muscle attached to the area marked in the given image is the gluteus maximus. The gluteus maximus is the largest muscle in the gluteal region and is primarily responsible for extending the hip joint, which means it helps to move the thigh backward. This action is commonly referred to as hip extension.
  • Additionally, the gluteus maximus also assists in lateral rotation of the hip joint. Lateral rotation refers to the outward rotation of the thigh away from the midline of the body.

Action of the Hip joint, corresponding muscles and their innervation:

Action

Muscles

Nerve supply

 

 

 

Flexion
  • Psoas major (chief flexor)

Anterior rami of L1, L2, L3
  • Iliacus (chief flexor)
  • Sartorius
  • Rectus femoris
  • Pectineus

 

Femoral nerve (L2, L3)

 

 

Extension
  • Gluteus maximus (chief extensor)

Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2)
  • Hamstring muscles

 

Tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)

 

 

Abduction
  • Gluteus medius and minimus (chief abductors)
  • Tensor fasciae latae

Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1)

 

 

 

Adduction
  • Adductor longus
  • Adductor brevis
  • Adductor magnus (chief adductors)
  • Gracilis

Obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4)
  • Pectineus

 

Double nerve supply (Femoral nerve and obturator nerve)

 

 

Medial rotation
  • Anterior fibres of gluteus minimus and medius (chief medial rotators)
  • Tensor fasciae latae

Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1)

 

 

 

 

 

 

Lateral rotation
  • Piriformis

Ventral rami of S1, S2
  • Obturator externus

Posterior division of obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4)
  • Obturator internus and
  • Associated gemelli,
  • Quadratus femoris (These muscles are generally termed short rotators)

Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1, S2)

Flexion and medial rotation (Option A): Flexion of the hip joint involves bringing the thigh forward, towards the abdomen. The gluteus maximus acts opposite to this motion by extending the hip, so it is not involved in hip flexion. Medial rotation refers to the inward rotation of the thigh towards the midline of the body, which is also not a primary action of the gluteus maximus.

Adduction and lateral rotation (Option B): Adduction involves bringing the thigh towards the midline of the body. The gluteus maximus is not directly involved in hip adduction. Lateral rotation is the correct action associated with the gluteus maximus, as explained earlier.

Abduction and medial rotation (Option C): Abduction refers to moving the thigh away from the midline of the body, which is not a primary action of the gluteus maximus. Medial rotation, as mentioned earlier, is not a primary action of the gluteus maximus.

questions.text: The artery that is palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Posterior tibial artery

Explanation:

  • The posterior tibial artery runs posterior to the medial malleolus, between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal (Achilles) tendon.
  • It is commonly palpated at this location to assess peripheral circulation, especially in conditions like peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

Arrangement of Structures Under the Flexor Retinaculum (Medial to Lateral)

Mnemonic: Tom Dick ANd Harry

  • T: Tibialis posterior
  • D: Flexor Digitorum longus
  • A: Posterior tibial Artery
  • N: Tibial Nerve
  • H: Flexor Hallucis longus

Incorrect Options:

Anterior tibial artery (Option A): The anterior tibial artery is located on the anterior aspect of the leg, and it travels through the anterior compartment. It is not palpated between the medial malleolus (inner ankle) and the calcaneal tendon (Achilles tendon).

Dorsalis pedis artery (Option C): The dorsalis pedis artery is located on the dorsal (top) aspect of the foot, specifically between the first and second metatarsal bones. It is not palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon.

Popliteal artery (Option D): The popliteal artery is located behind the knee joint in the popliteal fossa. It is not palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon.

questions.text: A patient has lost sensation over the dorsum of the foot and medial four toes. There is the associated difficulty of eversion of the foot. Which nerve injury is likely to be the reason for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Superficial peroneal nerve

Explanation:

  • The superficial peroneal nerve provides sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot and medial four toes, except for the web space between the first and second toes (which is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve).
  • It also supplies the lateral compartment muscles (fibularis longus and brevis), which are responsible for foot eversion.
  • Therefore, an injury to this nerve results in loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot and difficulty with eversion.

Fracture of the neck of fibula → Common peroneal nerve injury

Features of Common Peroneal Nerve Injury:

  • Loss of dorsiflexion → Foot drop
  • Complete loss of eversion
  • No loss of complete inversion (Tibialis posterior intact via tibial nerve)
  • Loss of extension of great toe and lateral four toes
  • Complete sensory loss on dorsum of foot (except lateral part)

Injury of Tibial Nerve

Injury of Superficial Peroneal Nerve

Injury of Deep Peroneal Nerve

Loss of plantar flexion

Eversion completely affected

Loss of dorsiflexion – foot drop
  • No loss of complete inversion (because of tibialis anterior supplied by deep peroneal nerve is intact)
  • Loss of flexion of great toe
  • Loss of flexion of lateral four toes
  • Paralysis of all muscles of sole
  • Loss of sensory supply over sole

Sensory loss on major part of dorsum except medial side of foot and lateral side of foot and lateral side of little finger
  • Inversion not completely affected because tibialis posterior functional
  • Loss of extension of great toe
  • Loss of extension of lateral four toes
  • Sensory loss on the area between great and second toe

Incorrect Options:

Deep peroneal nerve (Option A):

  • Supplies the anterior compartment of the leg
  • Provides sensation only to the first web space between the first and second toes.
  • Injury would cause foot drop, not loss of eversion.

Common peroneal nerve (Option C):

  • The common peroneal nerve branches into the superficial and deep peroneal nerves.
  • Injury would cause a wider deficit, including foot drop (due to deep peroneal involvement) and loss of eversion and sensation over the dorsum of the foot.
  • The given symptoms are specific to superficial peroneal nerve injury only.

Posterior tibial nerve (Option D):

  • Supplies the posterior compartment of the leg.
  • Provides sensation to the sole of the foot, not the dorsum.
  • Injury affects plantar flexion and sensation of the sole, not eversion.

questions.text: Identify the labelled tarsal bone in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Navicular

Explanation:

  • There are 7 tarsal bones in the foot.
  • The Navicular is located medially in the midfoot between the talus posteriorly and the 3 cuneiform bones anteriorly.

Bone Group

Bones

Description & Function

Tarsals

 

Provide mechanical support and structure to the foot.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Proximal Group

 

Talus

Transmits body weight to the foot.

 

Articulates at three joints:

 

Superiorly: Ankle joint (tibia/fibula)

 

Inferiorly: Subtalar joint (calcaneus)

 

Anteriorly: Talonavicular joint (navicular)

Calcaneus

Largest tarsal bone, forms the heel.

 

Articulates at two joints:

 

Superiorly: Subtalar joint (talus)

 

Anteriorly: Calcaneocuboid joint (cuboid)

Intermediate Group

 

Navicular

Boat-shaped; articulates with talus, cuneiforms, and cuboid.

 

Has a tuberosity for tibialis posterior tendon attachment.

Distal Group

 

Cuboid

Lateral; articulates with calcaneus and fourth/fifth metatarsals.

 

Features a groove for fibularis longus tendon.

Cuneiforms (3)

Medial, intermediate, lateral; wedge-shaped.

 

Help form the transverse arch; attach to various muscles.

Metatarsals

 

I-V (1-5)

Connect tarsals to phalanges; numbered medial to lateral.

 

Have a head, neck, shaft, and base; facilitate movement and support.

Phalanges

 

Great Toe: 2 (proximal, distal)

Toes 2-5: 3 each (proximal, intermediate, distal).

 

Each phalanx has a base, shaft, and head; provide structure to toes.

Incorrect Options:

Calcaneus (Option A): is the largest of the tarsal bones in the foot's heel. It bears the weight of the body as the heel touches the ground.

Cuboid (Option B): is the lateral bone of the foot lying in front of the calcaneus and behind the fourth and fifth metatarsal bones.

Talus (Option D): is the second largest tarsal bone, which lies above the calcaneus in the hindfoot.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given image
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B.

  • The marked structure shown in the above image is the anterior superior iliac spine.
  • A bony projection is present at the anterior end of the iliac crest. This is called the anterior superior iliac spine.
  • This projection provides attachment to the lateral end of the inguinal ligament. It can be easily felt at the lateral end of the fold of the groin.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Ischial spine is superior to the ischial tuberosity.

Option C. Anterior inferior iliac spine is the lower half of the anterior border of the ilium that projects forward.

Option D. Ischial tuberosity is the lower end of the body of ischium (part of the hip bone).

questions.text: Abduction at the hip joint is done by
questions.solution:
Correct option : B. 

  • Explanation: Abduction at the hip joint, which refers to moving the leg away from the midline of the body, is primarily performed by the gluteus medius muscle.
  • The gluteus medius is a broad, thick muscle located on the lateral aspect of the hip. It acts as a powerful abductor of the hip joint and plays a crucial role in maintaining stability during activities such as walking and running.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Gluteus maximus: The gluteus maximus is the largest muscle of the buttocks and primarily functions in extending and externally rotating the hip joint. While it can assist in abduction, it is not the primary muscle responsible for this movement.

Option C. Obturator internus: The obturator internus is a deep muscle of the hip that acts as an external rotator of the hip joint. It does not contribute significantly to hip abduction.

Option D. Quadratus femoris: The quadratus femoris is a deep muscle of the hip that assists in hip joint stabilization and contributes to hip rotation. It is not a primary muscle involved in hip abduction.

questions.text: Identify the marked tendon in the diagram:
questions.solution:
Correct option :A

  • Explanation: In the provided diagram, the marked tendon corresponds to the Extensor hallucis longus.
  • The Extensor hallucis longus is a muscle located in the anterior compartment of the leg. It originates from the middle third of the fibula and inserts onto the base of the distal phalanx of the great toe.
  • Its main action is to extend (dorsiflex) the great toe at the metatarsophalangeal joint and assist in dorsiflexion of the ankle joint.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Flexor hallucis longus: This muscle is located in the posterior compartment of the leg and is responsible for flexing the great toe.

Option C. Extensor digitorum longus: This muscle is also located in the anterior compartment of the leg and is responsible for extending (dorsiflexing) the lateral four toes.

Option D. Tibialis anterior: This muscle is located in the anterior compartment of the leg and is responsible for dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot

questions.text: Foot drop is caused by damage to:
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Common peroneal nerve:

Foot drop is commonly caused by damage to the common peroneal nerve, also known as the common fibular nerve. The common peroneal nerve innervates the muscles responsible for ankle dorsiflexion and foot eversion. Damage to this nerve can occur due to various factors such as trauma, compression, nerve entrapment, or underlying medical conditions.
 

Incorrect Option:

Option B: Femoral nerve:

The femoral nerve primarily innervates the muscles of the anterior thigh, including the quadriceps femoris muscle group. It is not directly responsible for ankle dorsiflexion or foot drop.

Option C: Tibial nerve:

The tibial nerve innervates the muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg, including the calf muscles that are involved in ankle plantar flexion. Damage to the tibial nerve may result in difficulty with plantar flexion but is not a common cause of foot drop.

Option D: Sciatic nerve:

The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body and consists of two components: the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve. While damage to the sciatic nerve can potentially cause foot drop, it is more specifically attributed to damage to the common peroneal nerve, which is a branch of the sciatic nerve.

questions.text: Identify the marked bony process?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Radial head:

  • Radial head: The radial head is a rounded bony structure located at the proximal end of the radius bone. It articulates with the capitulum of the humerus to form the radiocapitular joint, allowing rotational movements of the forearm. 

Incorrect options:

Option A - Capitulum: The capitulum is a bony prominence located on the distal end of the humerus. It articulates with the head of the radius to form the radio capitular joint.

Option B - Olecranon: The olecranon is a bony process located at the proximal end of the ulna, forming the prominent bony tip of the elbow. It serves as the insertion point for the triceps brachii muscle.

Option C - Trochlea: The trochlea is a structure located on the distal end of the humerus and plays a crucial role in the formation of the elbow joint. It articulates with the trochlear notch of the ulna, allowing flexion and extension movements of the forearm.

questions.text: Foot eversion is caused by?
questions.solution:
Correct option: B 

  • Peroneus longus: The peroneus longus muscle, also known as the fibularis longus muscle, is located on the lateral side of the leg. It plays a significant role in foot eversion. When the peroneus longus contracts, it pulls the foot outward, causing eversion.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Extensor digitorum: The extensor digitorum muscle is located on the anterior aspect of the leg and primarily functions to extend the digits (toes) and dorsiflex the foot. It is not directly involved in foot eversion.

Option C: Tibialis anterior: The tibialis anterior muscle is located on the anterior aspect of the leg. Its primary action is dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot. It is not directly involved in foot eversion.

Option D: Tibialis posterior: The tibialis posterior muscle is located on the posterior aspect of the leg. Its primary action is plantarflexion and inversion of the foot. It works in the opposite direction of foot eversion.

questions.text: Which nerve is most likely to be affected in a patient who underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein and is now experiencing paresthesia and sensory loss over the inner side of the leg and foot?
questions.solution:
Answer B - Saphenous nerve

  • The saphenous nerve is a purely sensory branch of the femoral nerve (L3-L4) that supplies sensation to the medial leg and foot. During coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), the great saphenous vein (GSV) is commonly harvested for the bypass procedure.
  • Since the saphenous nerve runs alongside the GSV in the leg, it is highly susceptible to injury during vein harvesting, leading to paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

Superficial peroneal nerve (option A): Provides sensory innervation to the anterolateral lower leg and dorsum of the foot. Unlikely to be affected in CABG as it is located in the lateral compartment of the leg.

Femoral nerve (option C): Provides motor innervation to the anterior thigh muscles and sensory innervation to the anterior and medial thigh. Injury would cause weakness of quadriceps and loss of knee jerk reflex, which is not described in the question.

Sural nerve (option D): Provides sensory innervation to the lateral foot and posterolateral calf. Not involved in medial leg and foot sensation, making it an unlikely option.

questions.text: The action of the muscle attached to the marked area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C : The action of the muscle attached to the marked area is abduction.

The muscle attached to the lateral surface of the greater trochanter is the gluteus Medius muscle. It plays a crucial role in the abduction of the hip joint. Abduction refers to the movement of a body part away from the midline of the body. In the case of the hip joint, abduction involves moving the leg away from the body's midline, out to the side.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Flexion refers to bending or decreasing the angle between two body parts. The action of the gluteus Medius muscle is not primarily related to flexion.

Option B: Adduction refers to the movement of a body part towards the midline of the body. The gluteus Medius muscle is not directly involved in adduction but rather acts as an antagonist to the adductor muscles.

Option D: Extension refers to straightening or increasing the angle between two body parts. The gluteus Medius muscle does not primarily contribute to extension but rather to abduction.

questions.text: Which muscle is not involved in the inversion of foot?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C.

  • Peroneus longus: The peroneus longus muscle, also known as fibularis longus, is located on the lateral side of the leg. It is primarily responsible for eversion (turning outward) of the foot, not inversion. Eversion is the opposite movement of inversion and involves turning the sole of the foot outward.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Tibialis anterior: The tibialis anterior muscle is located on the front (anterior) side of the leg. It is responsible for dorsiflexion (lifting) of the foot and inversion of the foot. It plays an important role in controlling the foot position during walking and running.

Option B. Tibialis posterior: The tibialis posterior muscle is located on the back (posterior) side of the leg. It is a powerful muscle that contributes to both inversion and plantar flexion (pointing) of the foot. It helps to maintain the arch of the foot and provides stability during walking and running.

Option D. Extensor hallucis longus: The extensor hallucis longus muscle is located on the front (anterior) side of the leg. It is responsible for dorsiflexion of the foot and extension of the big toe. While it does not directly contribute to inversion of the foot, it plays a role in maintaining the foot's position during various movements.

questions.text: In which compartment of the leg is the neurovascular bundle NOT present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: 

  • The neurovascular bundle refers to a grouping of blood vessels, nerves, and lymphatic vessels that travel together in a common sheath. In the leg, the neurovascular bundle is absent in the posterior superficial compartment.

Incorrect options:

Option A Lateral compartment: The lateral compartment of the leg contains the fibularis (peroneal) muscles and their associated blood vessels and nerves. While the specific arrangement of the neurovascular bundle may vary, it is generally present in the lateral compartment.

Option C: Posterior deep compartment: The posterior deep compartment of the leg contains the deep muscles, such as the tibialis posterior, flexor digitorum longus, and flexor hallucis longus, along with their associated blood vessels and nerves. The neurovascular bundle is typically present in this compartment.

Option D: Anterior compartment: The anterior compartment of the leg contains the muscles responsible for dorsiflexion of the foot and toe extension, such as the tibialis anterior and extensor digitorum longus. It also houses the anterior tibial artery and its branches, as well as the deep peroneal nerve. The neurovascular bundle is present in this compartment.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is/are supplied by the superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct answers- Option A Peroneus longus and Peroneus brevis

Explanation

  • Superficial peroneal nerve - Aka superficial fibular nerve. It is the nerve of the lateral compartment of the leg. It supplies peroneus longus and peroneus brevis.
  • The extensor digitorum longus (EDL) (Option B ruled out) muscle is innervated by the deep fibular nerve, also known as the deep peroneal nerve.
  • The tibialis anterior (Option C ruled out) muscle is supplied by the deep fibular nerve (also known as the deep peroneal nerve).

questions.text: What is the primary action of this muscle attached to the area marked?
questions.solution:
Correct answer

Option A) Abduction of the thigh

Explanation

Piriformis Muscle

Attachments:

  • Origin: Anterior sacrum (3 parts), gluteal surface of ilium near posterior inferior iliac spine, sacroiliac joint capsule.
  • Insertion: Medial upper border of the greater trochanter of the femur.

Key Features: Fills most of the greater sciatic foramen, acting as a crucial landmark.

Associated Structures:

  • Superior: Superior gluteal nerve and vessel.
  • Inferior: Inferior gluteal nerve and vessels, sciatic nerve, posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh, nerves to quadratus femoris and obturator internus, internal pudendal vessels, pudendal nerve.

Vascular Supply: Primarily by the superior gluteal artery; also by gemellar branches of internal pudendal, inferior gluteal, and lateral sacral arteries.

Innervation: Superior gluteal nerve and ventral rami of S1 and S2.

Actions: Laterally rotates the extended thigh and abducts the flexed thigh.(Option A)

Testing: No isolated test; dysfunction assessed by abducting thighs in a seated position, looking for buttock pain.

questions.text: A man sustained trauma on the lateral side of his right knee. Two days later, he complains of difficulty in walking, as his toes keep dragging on the ground. He also notices numbness over the upper lateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Common peroneal nerve:

Explanation:

A man with lateral right knee trauma now has foot drop and numbness over the upper lateral leg and dorsum of the foot, indicating injury to the Common Peroneal Nerve.

  • Supply: Common peroneal nerve branches from the sciatic nerve. It wraps around the neck of the fibula and then divides into two major branches:
    • Superficial peroneal nerve → Peroneus longus and Peroneus brevis (motor supply) → Eversion of the foot.
    • Deep peroneal nerve → Dorsiflexion of the foot and toes and extension of the toes (motor supply)
      • Tibialis anterior
      • Extensor hallucis longus
      • Extensor digitorum longus
      • Peroneus tertius
      • Extensor digitorum brevis
  • Mechanism of Trauma: Trauma to the lateral side of the knee, especially around the fibular neck, is a common site of injury to the common peroneal nerve, where it is superficial and vulnerable.
  • Symptoms:
    • Foot drop (toes drag while walking) → due to loss of dorsiflexion (caused by paralysis of muscles innervated by the deep peroneal nerve).
    • Numbness over the upper lateral leg and dorsum of foot → sensory supply of the common peroneal nerve and its superficial branch.

Incorrect Options:

  • Tibial nerve (Option A) affects plantarflexion and sensation on the sole of the foot - not consistent with symptoms.
  • Deep peroneal nerve (Option C) controls dorsiflexion but doesn't explain sensory loss over the lateral leg and most of the dorsum of the foot.
  • Femoral nerve (Option D) innervates anterior thigh muscles - not involved in foot dorsiflexion or lateral leg sensation.

questions.text: In the given image which vein is mainly affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Great saphenous vein:

Explanation:

  • The image depicts varicose veins following the path of the great saphenous vein, the primary vein affected is the great saphenous vein.

Great Saphenous Vein (GSV)

Origin
  • Arises on the dorsum of the foot, as a continuation of the medial marginal vein

Course
  • Ascends in front of the medial malleolus
  • Runs along the medial leg
  • Courses behind the knee
  • Inclines forward in the thigh
  • Passes through the saphenous opening into the femoral vein

Tributaries
  • Dorsal venous arch of the foot
  • Medial marginal vein
  • Posterior arch vein
  • Calf vein
  • Accessory saphenous vein
  • Anterior cutaneous vein of the thigh
  • Superficial epigastric, circumflex iliac, and external pudendal veins

Valves
  • Contains 10-20 valves, more concentrated in the leg

Clinical Significance
  • Commonly used in surgical grafting, especially for coronary artery bypass
  • Varicose veins: Dilated, tortuous veins due to valve incompetence, commonly in GSV and tributaries

Incorrect Options:

Short saphenous vein (Option B) runs along the posterior leg and is less commonly affected.

Femoral vein (Option C) is a deep vein, and varicosities usually involve superficial veins.

Perforator veins (Option D) connect superficial veins to deep veins but are not the primary site of varicosities.

questions.text: The artery that is palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Posterior tibial artery:

Explanation:

  • The posterior tibial artery runs posterior to the medial malleolus, between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal (Achilles) tendon.
  • It is commonly palpated at this location to assess peripheral circulation, especially in conditions like peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

Arrangement of Structures Under the Flexor Retinaculum (Medial to Lateral)

Mnemonic: Tom Dick ANd Harry

  • T: Tibialis posterior
  • D: Flexor Digitorum longus
  • A: Posterior tibial Artery
  • N: Tibial Nerve
  • H: Flexor Hallucis longus


Incorrect Options:

  • Anterior tibial artery (Option A): The anterior tibial artery is located on the anterior aspect of the leg, and it travels through the anterior compartment. It is not palpated between the medial malleolus (inner ankle) and the calcaneal tendon (Achilles tendon).
  • Dorsalis pedis artery (Option C): The dorsalis pedis artery is located on the dorsal (top) aspect of the foot, specifically between the first and second metatarsal bones. It is not palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon.
  • Popliteal artery (Option D): The popliteal artery is located behind the knee joint in the popliteal fossa. It is not palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon.

questions.text: A patient presents with meralgia paraesthetica. Based on the diagram, identify the nerve involved in this condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - C:

Explanation:

  • Meralgia Paraesthetica results from compression or irritation of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve (L2-L3), which corresponds to the nerve labeled C in the diagram.
  • It is marked by tingling and numbness in the outer thigh that worsens with prolonged sitting and improves with standing or walking.
  • It results from compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve → L2 and L3 nerve roots.
  • Lateral Femoral Cutaneous Nerve
    • Provides purely sensory innervation to the skin over the lateral aspect of the thigh.
    • This nerve is significant in conditions such as meralgia paresthetica, where it can become compressed, leading to tingling and pain in the outer thigh.
    • Most commonly injured during McRoberts manure & Laparoscopic hernia surgery.

A: L1–T12 (Option A): These spinal levels correspond to the iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves, which do not cause meralgia paraesthetica.

B: L1–L2 (Option B): These roots form the genitofemoral nerve, unrelated to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve involved in this condition.

D: L2–L4 (Option D): These roots contribute to the femoral nerve, which is different from the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve responsible for meralgia paraesthetica.

questions.text: A Patients presents with ankle pain and swelling after a forceful eversion injury. Based on the mechanism of injury, which ligament is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Deltoid ligament

Explanation: A forceful eversion injury causes the foot to twist outward, placing stress on the medial structures of the ankle, most commonly resulting in damage to the Deltoid Ligament, the strong medial stabilizer of the joint.

  • A strong, fan-shaped ligament on the medial side of the ankle.
  • Composed of four parts:
    • Tibionavicular
    • Tibiocalcaneal
    • Posterior tibiotalar
    • Anterior tibiotalar
  • Function: Stabilizes the ankle joint and resists eversion forces.
    • Damage to this ligament can lead to medial ankle pain, swelling, and instability.
  • Injury (eversion):
    • Occur: Foot is forcefully twisted outward (away from the midline) → Stresses the medial (inner) side of the ankle.
    • Less common than inversion injuries.

Incorrect Options:

Option A : Anterior talofibular ligament is injured in inversion injuries, not eversion; part of the lateral ligament complex.

Option B: Calcaneofibular ligament is also part of the lateral side, damaged in inversion injuries.

Option D:Posterior talofibular ligament is rarely injured alone; involved in severe inversion injuries.

questions.text: Injury at which of the following marked sites causes failure of dorsiflexion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 3

Explanation:

  • The injury to common fibular nerve causes failure of dorsiflexion, thus the marked structure 3 i.e. neck of fibula is the right answer

Sciatic Nerve

Origin and Course
  • The thickest nerve in the body.
  • Arises from the ventral rami of L4–S3 spinal nerves.
  • Exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis and descends between the greater trochanter and ischial tuberosity along the back of the thigh.
  • Divides into the tibial and common peroneal nerves above the popliteal fossa.

Distribution

Motor:

  • Undivided Trunk: Supplies all muscles of the back of the thigh (hip extension, knee flexion).
  • Tibial Nerve: Innervates leg muscles (flexion) and foot muscles (plantar flexion).
  • Common Peroneal Nerve: Supplies leg muscles (dorsiflexion).

Sensory:

  • Tibial Nerve: Supplies skin on the back of the calf, heel, lateral border of the foot, and sole.
  • Common Peroneal Nerve: Supplies skin on the anterolateral and lateral surfaces of the leg and dorsum of the foot (except for the deep peroneal nerve area).

Clinical correlation

Injury of the sciatic nerve:

  • Causes: Penetrating wounds, posterior hip dislocation, pelvic fractures, total hip replacement, misplaced injections in the gluteal region.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Inability to extend the thigh and flex the knee (hamstring paralysis).
    • Loss of all movements below the knee (foot drop) leading to flail foot and high-stepping gait.
    • Loss of sensation on the back of the thigh, entire leg, and foot (except for the saphenous nerve area).

Sciatica:

  • Shooting pain along the sciatic nerve distribution (buttock, posterior thigh, lateral leg, dorsum of the foot).
  • Compression/irritation of L4–S3 spinal nerve roots due to herniated lumbar discs.

Neuropathy:

  • Entrapment in the piriformis muscle can lead to piriformis syndrome.

                              Sciatic Nerve Course

 

                     Branches of Sciatic Nerve

questions.text: Patient presenting with pain in back of thigh and leg after lifting heavy weights. Which segment is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - S2:

  • Pain in the back of the thigh and leg after lifting heavy weights is most commonly associated with the S2 nerve root. The S2 nerve root contributes to the sensation in the posterior aspect of the thigh and leg and can be affected by conditions such as sciatica or disc herniation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - L4: The L4 nerve root typically affects the anterior and medial aspect of the thigh, as well as the medial side of the leg and foot. It is less likely to be associated with pain specifically in the back of the thigh and leg.

Option B - L5: The L5 nerve root affects the lateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot. While it can cause pain radiating down the leg, it is not typically associated with pain specifically in the back of the thigh.

Option C - S1: The S1 nerve root affects the posterior and lateral aspects of the leg and the heel. Pain in the back of the thigh and leg can be related to S1, but S2 is more directly associated with the described pain after heavy lifting.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with sciatica had tender hamstrings. Which of the following supplies a hybrid muscle, which is spared in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Obturator Nerve:

  • This nerve supplies the adductor muscles of the thigh, which are part of the hybrid muscle group that is spared in sciatica. The obturator nerve is primarily responsible for innervating the adductor muscles (adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus, and gracilis) which are not affected in sciatica, as sciatica mainly involves the sciatic nerve and its branches.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Femoral Nerve: This nerve innervates the quadriceps and other muscles of the anterior thigh. In sciatica, the femoral nerve is generally not directly involved, but the tender hamstrings are more related to the sciatic nerve and its branches.

Option B - Common Peroneal Nerve: This is a branch of the sciatic nerve, and sciatica can affect it, leading to symptoms like foot drop. It does not provide significant innervation to the hybrid muscle group that is mentioned in this context.

Option D - Tibial Nerve: This is another branch of the sciatic nerve, and it innervates the posterior compartment of the leg and the plantar aspect of the foot. It is involved in sciatica and is not spared in this condition.

questions.text: The muscle attached to the marked bony structure is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ilio-psoas

Explanation:

  • The iliopsoas muscle consists of the illacus and psoas major muscles.
  • It attaches to the lesser trochanter of the femur and primarily originates from the iliac fossa and lumbar vertebrae.
  • The iliopsoas muscle is a major hip flexor and assists in anterior pelvic tilt.

Gluteus maximus (Option B): Gluteus maximus is inserted into the iliotibial tract and gluteal tuberosity of the femur.

Gluteus medius (Option C): Gluteus medius inserts into the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.

Sartorius (Option D): Sartorius inserts into the medial side of the proximal tibia.

questions.text: Muscle inserted on lesser trochanter?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Psoas major muscle

Explanation:

  • Long muscle coming from the Lumbar vertebra
  • Inserts into lesser trochanter - femur bone
  • Innervated by anterior rami of L1, 2, 3
  • Flexes the thigh

Psoas minor (Option B):

  • Inserted into the illiopectinal eminence
  • Innervated by the anterior rami of L1, 2
  • Flexes the thigh

Obturator internus (Option C):

  • Inserted into greater trochanter of the femur
  • Innervated by the nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1)
  • Laterally rotates extended thigh and abducts flexed hip

Piriformis (Option D):

  • Inserts superiorly into the tip of the greater trochanter.
  • Innervated by the branches of anterior rami (S1, S2)
  • Laterally rotates extended thigh and abducts flexed hip

questions.text: Identify the muscle that is defective in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gluteus medius and Gluteus minimus

Explanation:

  • The Gluteus medius and Gluteus minimus are responsible for the abduction and medial rotation of the thigh and are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.
  • A positive Trendelenburg test, which is indicated by a drop in the pelvic alignment when standing on one leg, is characteristic of a defect in these muscles. (as shown in the image)
  • This condition suggests a superior gluteal nerve injury, which results in a lurching motion towards the side of the lesion.

questions.text: A surgical procedure is performed on the great saphenous vein, around 2.5 cm anterior to the medial malleolus. Which of the following structures is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Saphenous nerve
 

Explanation: The great saphenous vein passes anterior to the medial malleolus and is closely associated with the saphenous nerve; therefore, it is more prone to injury during this procedure.

Great Saphenous Vein

  • Origin:
    • Begins at the medial end of the dorsal venous arch.
  • Course:
    • Ascends 2.5 cm in front of the medial malleolus, along the medial aspect of the tibia with the saphenous nerve.
    • Passes posterior to the medial condyles of the tibia and femur.
    • Runs posterior to the patella and ascends along the medial side of the femur.
    • Pierces the cribriform fascia and passes through the saphenous opening.
    • Drains into the femoral vein after piercing the femoral sheath.

Clinical Aspects

  • Venesection:
    • Performed at the ankle in emergencies.
    • Care must be taken to avoid damaging the saphenous nerve (as it accompanies the vein).
  • Coronary Bypass Surgery:
    • Commonly used as a graft for bypass surgery.
    • The vein must be reversed to prevent its valves from obstructing blood flow in the graft.

questions.text: In the given image, the physician is trying to palpate which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Posterior tibial artery

Explanation:

The posterior tibial artery is present in the posterior aspect of the leg and, runs posterior to the tibia, and supplies the calf region.

Arrangement of Structures Under the Flexor Retinaculum (Medial to Lateral)

Mnemonic: Tom Dick ANd Harry

  • T: Tibialis posterior
  • D: Flexor Digitorum longus
  • A: Posterior tibial Artery
  • N: Tibial Nerve
  • H: Flexor Hallucis longus

 

Anterior tibial artery (Option A): Anterior tibial artery is present in the anterior aspect of the leg.

Dorsalis pedis artery (Option C): The anterior tibial artery continuous as the dorsalis pedis artery

Lateral plantar artery (Option D): The posterior tibial artery passes under the flexor retinaculum on the medial side of the ankle and divides into the medial and lateral plantar arteries to supply the sole.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female, who works as a maid complained of knee pain and swelling. Which of the following area gets damaged in Housemaid’s knee?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - B (Prepatellar bursa)

  • The correct answer is option b (Prepatellar bursa), as housemaid's knee involves inflammation of the prepatellar bursa due to repeated kneeling or trauma to the front of the knee.Housemaid's knee, also known as prepatellar bursitis, involves inflammation of the prepatellar bursa. The prepatellar bursa is located just in front of the patella (kneecap) and can become inflamed due to repetitive kneeling or trauma to the area. This condition is often seen in individuals who perform activities that involve prolonged kneeling, such as housemaids or carpet layers.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A (Suprapatellar bursa): The suprapatellar bursa is located above the patella (kneecap) and helps reduce friction between the femur (thigh bone) and the quadriceps tendon. This bursa is not commonly associated with housemaid's knee.

Option C - C (Infrapatellar bursa): The infrapatellar bursa is located below the patella, between the patellar ligament and the tibia (shin bone). It helps reduce friction during knee movements. Inflammation of this bursa is known as "clergyman's knee" or "Clergyman's bursitis," which is caused by excessive kneeling and friction.

Option D - D (Pes anserine bursa): The pes anserine bursa is located on the inner side of the knee, just below the joint. It is situated between the tendons of the sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus muscles and the underlying tibia. Inflammation of this bursa can lead to pes anserine bursitis, which typically presents as pain and tenderness on the inner side of the knee. This condition is not directly related to housemaid's knee.

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the Gluteus maximus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inferior gluteal nerve
 

Explanation:

  • The inferior gluteal nerve (from the sacral plexus, specifically from L5, S1, and S2 nerve roots) primarily innervates the gluteus maximus muscle.
  • It arises from the posterior division of the sacral plexus and passes through the greater sciatic foramen to reach the gluteal region.
  • This nerve provides motor innervation to the gluteus maximus, which is the largest muscle in the buttocks and plays a significant role in movements such as hip extension and external rotation.

Action of the Hip joint, corresponding muscles, and their innervation:

Action

Muscles

Nerve supply

 

 

 

Flexion
  • Psoas major (chief flexor)

Anterior rami of L1, L2, L3
  • Iliacus (chief flexor)
  • Sartorius
  • Rectus femoris
  • Pectineus

 

Femoral nerve (L2, L3) (Option A)

 

 

Extension
  • Gluteus maximus (chief extensor)

Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2)
  • Hamstring muscles

 

Tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)

 

 

Abduction
  • Gluteus medius and minimus (chief abductors)
  • Tensor fasciae latae

Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1)

 

 

 

 

Adduction
  • Adductor longus
  • Adductor brevis
  • Adductor magnus (chief adductors)
  • Gracilis

Obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4) (Option C)
  • Pectineus

 

Double nerve supply (Femoral nerve and obturator nerve)

 

 

Medial rotation
  • Anterior fibres of gluteus minimus and medius (chief medial rotators)
  • Tensor fasciae latae

Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1)

(Option D)

 

 

 

 

 

 

Lateral rotation
  • Piriformis

Ventral rami of S1, S2
  • Obturator externus

Posterior division of obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4)
  • Obturator internus and
  • Associated gemelli,
  • Quadratus femoris (These muscles are generally termed short rotators)

Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1, S2)

questions.text: Lateral plantar nerve supplies which of the following muscles?

choices.text: Flexor digitorum brevis, Abductor hallucis, Flexor hallucis brevis
Flexor digitorum brevis, Abductor hallucis, Extensor digitorum brevis
Flexor digiti minimi brevis, Abductor hallucis, Abductor digiti minimi
Flexor digiti minimi brevis, Abductor digiti minimi, Adductor hallucis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Flexor digiti minimi brevis, Abductor digiti minimi, Adductor hallucis

Explanation:

The lateral plantar nerve is a branch of the tibial nerve and supplies several muscles in the foot, mainly located in the lateral side and the deep layers of the sole.

Muscles supplied by the lateral plantar nerve:

  • Abductor digiti minimi
  • Flexor digiti minimi brevis
  • Adductor hallucis
  • Quadratus plantae
  • 2nd, 3rd, and 4th lumbricals
  • Plantar interossei
  • Dorsal interossei

questions.text: Behind the medial malleolus and in front of Achilles which artery is present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Posterior tibial artery:

  • Posterior tibial artery: The posterior tibial artery is located behind the medial malleolus and in front of the Achilles tendon. It runs posterior to the medial malleolus and can be palpated in this region.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Peroneal artery: The peroneal artery (also known as the fibular artery) is located along the lateral side of the leg and is not found behind the medial malleolus. It supplies the lateral compartment of the leg.

Option C - Anterior tibial artery: The anterior tibial artery runs down the anterior part of the leg, in front of the interosseous membrane, and becomes the dorsalis pedis artery at the ankle. It is not located behind the medial malleolus.

Option D - Dorsalis pedis artery: The dorsalis pedis artery is located on the dorsum (top) of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female, who works as a maid complained of knee pain and swelling. Which of the following area gets damaged in Housemaid’s knee?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) B (Prepatellar bursa)

Explanation:

  • The correct answer is option b (Prepatellar bursa), as housemaid's knee involves inflammation of the prepatellar bursa due to repeated kneeling or trauma to the front of the knee.
  • Housemaid's knee, also known as prepatellar bursitis, involves inflammation of the prepatellar bursa.
  • The prepatellar bursa is located just in front of the patella (kneecap) and can become inflamed due to repetitive kneeling or trauma to the area.
  • This condition is often seen in individuals who perform activities that involve prolonged kneeling, such as housemaids or carpet layers.

Bursa Around Knee:

  • Suprapatellar bursa: Deep to quadriceps femoris. Communicates with knee joint.
  • Prepatellar bursa: Lies over the superficial surface of patella.
  • Housemaid’s knee – Prepatellar bursitis.
  • Infrapatellar bursa: Lies over patellar ligament.
  • Clergyman’s knee – Infrapatellar bursitis.
  • Anserine bursa: Lies between tibial collateral ligament and tendons of sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus.

 

A (Option A): The suprapatellar bursa is located above the patella (kneecap) and helps reduce friction between the femur (thigh bone) and the quadriceps tendon. This bursa is not commonly associated with housemaid's knee.

C (Option C): The infrapatellar bursa is located below the patella, between the patellar ligament and the tibia (shin bone). It helps reduce friction during knee movements. Inflammation of this bursa is known as "clergyman's knee" or "Clergyman's bursitis," which is caused by excessive kneeling and friction.

D (Option D): The pes anserine bursa is located on the inner side of the knee, just below the joint. It is situated between the tendons of the sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus muscles and the underlying tibia. Inflammation of this bursa can lead to pes anserine bursitis, which typically presents as pain and tenderness on the inner side of the knee. This condition is not directly related to housemaid's knee.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is palpated in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • The artery palpated in the image shown is the posterior tibial artery; it is palpated between the medial malleolus and Achilles tendon/tendocalcaneous. Locate the medial malleolus (the bony bump on the inside of the ankle). Place your index and middle fingers on the inside of the ankle and move your fingers behind the medial malleolus towards the back of the leg. You should be able to feel the posterior tibial artery pulsations in this area.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterior tibial artery: To palpate the anterior tibial artery, ask the patient to lie down or sit with their legs slightly bent. Locate the ankle bones (medial malleolus and lateral malleolus) and identify the space between them. Place your index and middle fingers on the space between the ankle bones and move your fingers upwards towards the top of the foot. You should be able to feel the anterior tibial artery pulsations in this area.

Option C - Dorsalis pedis artery: To palpate the dorsalis pedis artery, ask the patient to lie down or sit with their legs slightly bent. Locate the first and second metatarsal bones (the bones that connect to the big toe). Place your index and middle fingers on the top of the foot, just below the space between the first and second metatarsal bones, you can feel the pulsations there.

Option D - Popliteal artery: To palpate the popliteal artery, ask the patient to lie down on their stomach or to sit with their legs hanging off the edge of the exam table. Flex the knee to about 90 degrees. Use your fingers to locate the popliteal fossa, which is the small depression behind the knee joint. Feel for the pulsation of the artery in the middle of the fossa. Press your fingers gently into the popliteal fossa and feel for the pulsation of the artery.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not supplied by the superior gluteal nerve?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Piriformis

 

Explanation:

Piriformis is NOT supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. The piriformis is instead innervated by the nerve to piriformis, which arises from the sacral plexus (S1–S2).

 

Superior gluteal nerve (L4–S1) supplies:

  • Gluteus medius
  • Gluteus minimus
  • Tensor fasciae latae


 

 

Tensor Fasciae Latae

Gluteus Medius

Gluteus Minimus

Attachments
  • Origin: Outer lip of the iliac crest extending from the anterior superior iliac spine to the tubercle of the crest.

 

  • Insertion: Iliotibial tract 3–5 cm below the level of the greater trochanter.
  • Origin: Gluteal surface of the ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines
 
  • Insertion: Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.
  • Origin: Gluteal surfaces of the ilium between anterior & inferior gluteal lines.
 
  • Insertion: Anterior aspect of the Greater trochanter

Relations
  • Between gluteus medius and sartorius
  • Covered by fascia lata
  • Covered by gluteus maximus (posterior third)
  • Deep to gluteus minimus
  • Deep to gluteus medius
  • Related to hip joint capsule

Vascular Supply
  • Mainly from lateral circumflex femoral artery
  • Supplied by superior gluteal artery
  • Deep branch of superior gluteal artery
  • Trochanteric anastomosis
  • Main trunk and deep branch of superior gluteal artery
  • Trochanteric anastomosis

Innervation
  • Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)
  • Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)
  • Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)

Actions
  • Hip flexor and abductor
  • Stabilizes pelvis
  • Helps maintain
  • extended knee
  • Abducts thigh
  • Medial & lateral rotation of thigh
  • Supports pelvis during single-leg stance
  • Abducts thigh
  • Medial and lateral rotation of thigh

Testing
  • Depression below anterior superior iliac spine
  • Abduction against resistance
  • Medial rotation against resistance
  • Abduction against resistance
  • Medial rotation against resistance
  • Abduction against resistance

questions.text: What is the ligament that links the medial cuneiform bone to the base of the second metatarsal bone?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Lisfranc

 

Explanation:

The Lisfranc ligament connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the second metatarsal. It is a strong oblique ligament that stabilises the tarsometatarsal (TMT) joint and prevents excessive movement between the midfoot and forefoot.

 

Injury to this ligament leads to a Lisfranc injury, which involves displacement of the second metatarsal and can result in significant midfoot instability.

 

Anatomy:

  • The Lisfranc joint is formed by the metatarsal bones (M1 to M5) and the tarsal bones (cuneiform C1 to C3 and cuboid).
  • The Lisfranc ligament is a 3 part structure that joins the medial cuneiform to the 2nd metatarsal.
  • Interdigitating joints and strong ligaments support the five tarsometatarsal (TMT) joints.
  • The second metatarsal base fits into a recess formed by the medial, intermediate, and lateral cuneiforms.

 

Injury Mechanism:

  • Dislocations are rare and typically arise from twisting or crushing injuries, with the foot buckling at the midfoot–forefoot junction.
  • Often considered high-energy injuries, leading to extensive damage to the foot.
  • The direction of forefoot dislocation is not useful for treatment guidance or outcome prediction.

 

Clinical Features:

  • Suspect TMT dislocation or fracture-dislocation in patients with foot pain and swelling after high-velocity impacts (e.g., car accidents, falls).
  • About 20–30% of these injuries are initially missed.
  • Obvious deformity usually only occurs with severe injuries.

 

Imaging:

X-rays:

  • Interpretation can be challenging; systematic examination is crucial.
  • Focus on the alignment of the second and fourth metatarsals (oblique view):
    • The medial edge of the second metatarsal should align with the medial edge of the second cuneiform.
    • The medial edge of the fourth metatarsal should align with the medial side of the cuboid.
  • A true lateral view may show dorsal displacement of the second metatarsal base.



 

Advanced Imaging:

  • If fracture-dislocation is suspected, stress views may help, but a CT scan is more effective for assessing the extent of injury.

 

Treatment:

  • Undisplaced Sprains:
    • Require 4–6 weeks of cast or boot immobilization.
  • Subluxation or Dislocation:
    • Accurate reduction is necessary, often achieved through traction and manipulation under anesthesia.
    • The position is stabilized with percutaneous K-wires or screws, followed by cast immobilization (non-weight-bearing for 6–8 weeks).
  • Open Reduction:
    • If closed reduction fails, open reduction is essential.
    • Exposure of the second metatarsal base via a longitudinal incision for joint manipulation.
    • Fixation with K-wires or screws, followed by immobilization.

 

Complications:

  • Compartment Syndrome:
    • A tense, swollen foot may indicate serious compartment syndrome.
    • Measure intracompartmental pressures if suspected.
    • Prompt decompression through surgical incisions is critical; the wound is left open until swelling subsides.

Chopart ligament (option A): Related to the Chopart joint, which is the midtarsal (transverse tarsal) joint, connecting the hindfoot (talus and calcaneus) to the midfoot (navicular and cuboid). Not involved in the medial cuneiform–second metatarsal connection.

 

Spring ligament (option B): Also called the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, it connects the calcaneus to the navicular and supports the medial longitudinal arch of the foot. Does not link the medial cuneiform to the second metatarsal.

 

Deltoid ligament (option D): A strong medial ankle ligament, stabilising the talus within the ankle mortise. It is unrelated to the tarsometatarsal joints.

questions.text: Identify the tarsal bone labeled in the image below.
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Navicular

Explanation:

The navicular bone is a boat-shaped tarsal bone located on the medial side of the foot, between the talus (posteriorly) and the cuneiform bones (anteriorly). The X-ray shows a lateral view of the foot, with the navicular bone labeled in its characteristic position between the talus and the midfoot structures.

Tarsal Bones and Their Positions

Bone Group

Bones

Description & Function

Tarsals

Provide mechanical support and structure to the foot.

Proximal Group

Talus

Transmits body weight to the foot.

Articulates at three joints:

Superiorly: Ankle joint (tibia/fibula)

Inferiorly: Subtalar joint (calcaneus)

Anteriorly: Talonavicular joint (navicular)

Calcaneus

Largest tarsal bone, forms the heel.

Articulates at two joints:

Superiorly: Subtalar joint (talus)

Anteriorly: Calcaneocuboid joint (cuboid)

Intermediate Group

Navicular

Boat-shaped; articulates with talus, cuneiforms, and cuboid.

Has a tuberosity for tibialis posterior tendon attachment.

Distal Group

Cuboid

Lateral; articulates with calcaneus and fourth/fifth metatarsals.

Features a groove for fibularis longus tendon.

Cuneiforms (3)

Medial, intermediate, lateral; wedge-shaped.

Help form the transverse arch; attach to various muscles.

Metatarsals

I-V (1-5)

Connect tarsals to phalanges; numbered medial to lateral.

Have a head, neck, shaft, and base; facilitate movement and support.

Phalanges

Great Toe: 2 (proximal, distal)

Toes 2-5: 3 each (proximal, intermediate, distal).

Each phalanx has a base, shaft, and head; provide structure to toes.

Calcaneus (Option A): Incorrect because the calcaneus is located posteriorly and is the largest tarsal bone forming the heel.

Cuboid (Option B): Incorrect because the cuboid is on the lateral side of the foot, articulating with the 4th and 5th metatarsals.

Talus (Option D): Incorrect because the talus is superior to the navicular, articulating with the tibia and fibula to form the ankle joint.

questions.text: The prevention of lateral dislocation of the patella during knee flexion is by-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vastus Medialis

Explanation:

The vastus medialis, particularly its oblique fibers (VMO - Vastus Medialis Obliquus), plays a crucial role in preventing lateral dislocation of the patella by exerting a medial pull on the patella during knee flexion. This counteracts the lateral pull of the quadriceps, especially the vastus lateralis.

Patellar Stability and Dislocation Prevention

Structure

Role in Patellar Stability

Vastus Medialis (VMO)

Exerts a medial pull on the patella, preventing lateral displacement

Patellar Ligament

Connects the patella to the tibial tuberosity but does not prevent lateral dislocation

Gracilis

A medial thigh muscle responsible for hip adduction, not involved in patellar stability

Rectus Femoris

A major knee extensor, but does not prevent lateral displacement

Patellar Ligament (Option B): Incorrect because it primarily stabilizes the patella in the superior-inferior direction, not against lateral forces.

Gracilis (Option C): Incorrect because it is a medial thigh muscle involved in hip adduction and does not influence patellar stability.

Rectus Femoris (Option D): Incorrect because it is a knee extensor, contributing to overall quadriceps function but not directly preventing lateral patellar displacement.

questions.text: The dermatome of the area marked in the given below image is-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) L4

Explanation:

The area marked in the image corresponds to the medial aspect of the leg, which is supplied by the L4 dermatome. The L4 dermatome extends from the anteromedial thigh, over the knee, and down to the medial malleolus.

Dermatome Distribution of the Lower Limb

Dermatome

Region Supplied

L1

Inguinal region

L2

Anterior thigh

L3

Lower anterior thigh and medial knee

L4

Medial leg and medial malleolus

L5

Lateral leg, dorsum of foot, great toe

S1

Lateral foot, sole, little toe

S2

Posterior thigh and leg

S3-S5

Perineum and anal region

L5 (Option B): incorrect because it supplies the dorsum of the foot and lateral leg, not the medial leg.

S1 (Option C): incorrect because it supplies the lateral foot and sole, not the medial side.

S2 (Option D): incorrect because it is distributed over the posterior thigh and leg, not the anterior or medial aspect.

questions.text: Which artery is being palpated in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Posterior tibial artery

Explanation:

The image demonstrates palpation of the posterior tibial artery, which is typically assessed posterior to the medial malleolus, just behind the ankle joint. This pulse is an important clinical marker for peripheral circulation, especially in conditions like peripheral artery disease (PAD).

Arterial Supply of the Lower Limb

Artery

Origin

Course

Palpation Site

Clinical Importance

Posterior Tibial Artery

Popliteal artery

Runs posterior to medial malleolus

Behind medial malleolus

Evaluated in PAD (absent in vascular diseases)

Anterior Tibial Artery

Popliteal artery

Passes through interosseous membrane to anterior leg

Difficult to palpate directly

Supplies anterior compartment of the leg

Dorsalis Pedis Artery

Continuation of anterior tibial artery

Runs along dorsum of foot

Lateral to extensor hallucis longus tendon

Commonly used in vascular assessments

Popliteal Artery

Continuation of femoral artery

Located in popliteal fossa

Deep in the popliteal fossa

Can be affected in popliteal artery entrapment syndrome

Anterior tibial artery (Option A): incorrect because it is located in the anterior compartment of the leg and is not palpated posterior to the medial malleolus.

Dorsalis pedis artery (Option C): incorrect because it is palpated on the dorsum of the foot, lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon.

Popliteal artery (Option D): incorrect because it is located deep in the popliteal fossa and requires deep palpation behind the knee.

questions.text:
Which of the following branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery?

1. Superior gluteal artery

2. Inferior gluteal artery

3. Superior vesical artery

4. Middle rectal artery

5. Inferior vesical artery

6. Vaginal artery
questions.solution:
The anterior division of the internal iliac artery gives rise to multiple visceral and parietal branches supplying the pelvic organs, perineum, and lower limb. The correct answer includes all the relevant branches from this division.

Branches of the Internal Iliac Artery:

Division

Branches

Anterior Division (Primarily supplies pelvic organs, perineum, and medial thigh)

Inferior gluteal artery, superior vesical artery, middle rectal artery, inferior vesical artery, vaginal artery, obturator artery, internal pudendal artery, uterine artery

Posterior Division (Primarily supplies the pelvic wall and gluteal region)

Superior gluteal artery, iliolumbar artery, lateral sacral artery

1,2,3,5- (Option A) : Incorrect because superior gluteal artery (1) belongs to the posterior division.

2,3,4,6- (Option B) : Incorrect because it excludes inferior vesical artery (5), which is an anterior division branch.

1,4,5,6- (Option D) : Incorrect because superior gluteal artery (1) belongs to the posterior division.

questions.text: A boy with a history of a fall from a tree presents with a lurching gait and dragging of his feet. Which of the following structures are involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1

Explanation:

  • The gluteus medius is essential for stabilizing the pelvis during walking. Injury to this muscle or its innervation (superior gluteal nerve) leads to a lurching gait (Trendelenburg gait) where the patient compensates by shifting weight toward the affected side to prevent pelvic drop.

Gluteus Muscles and Trendelenburg Gait

 

Tensor Fasciae Latae

Gluteus Medius

Gluteus Minimus

Attachments
  • Origin: Outer lip of the iliac crest extending from the anterior superior iliac spine to the tubercle of the crest.

 

  • Insertion: Iliotibial tract 3–5 cm below the level of the greater trochanter.
  • Origin: Gluteal surface of the ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines

 

  • Insertion: Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.

 
  • Origin: Gluteal surfaces of the ilium between anterior & inferior gluteal lines.

 

  • Insertion: Anterior aspect of the Greater trochanter

Relations
  • Between gluteus medius and sartorius
  • Covered by fascia lata
  • Covered by gluteus maximus (posterior third)
  • Deep to gluteus minimus
  • Deep to gluteus medius
  • Related to hip joint capsule

Vascular Supply
  • Mainly from lateral circumflex femoral artery
  • Supplied by superior gluteal artery
  • Deep branch of superior gluteal artery
  • Trochanteric anastomosis
  • Main trunk and deep branch of superior gluteal artery
  • Trochanteric anastomosis

Innervation
  • Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)
  • Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)
  • Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)

Actions
  • Hip flexor and abductor
  • Stabilizes pelvis
  • Helps maintain extended knee
  • Abducts thigh
  • Medial & lateral rotation of thigh
  • Supports pelvis during single-leg stance
  • Abducts thigh
  • Medial and lateral rotation of thigh

Testing
  • Depression below anterior superior iliac spine
  • Abduction against resistance
  • Medial rotation against resistance
  • Abduction against resistance
  • Medial rotation against resistance
  • Abduction against resistance

Trendelenberg sign:

  • When the body's weight is balanced on one leg, the gluteal muscles on the supported side help elevate the opposite, unsupported side of the pelvis.
  • However, if there is a malfunction in the abductor mechanism, the Sound side sinks, which is referred to as a positive Trendelenburg sign (uncompensated).
  • This sign indicates issues with hip abductors, such as paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus; problems with the fulcrum, including congenital or pathological hip dislocations; and concerns related to body weight, such as an unhealed fracture of the femoral neck.
  • When patients with the gluteus medius and minimus paralysis walk, they have a characteristic lurching gait i.e., during the single leg supporting phase of walking, there is leaning of the trunk to the affected side known as the compensated Trendelenburg sign.
  • Duck waddling gait is seen when both the sides are affected.

1 (Gluteus maximus) (Option A): Incorrect – Gluteus maximus is responsible for hip extension. Injury causes difficulty in rising from a seated position but does not cause a lurching gait.

3 (Piriformis) (Option C): Incorrect – Piriformis primarily functions in hip external rotation. Injury leads to piriformis syndrome, which causes sciatica-like pain but does not cause a lurching gait.

4 (Sciatic nerve) (Option D): Incorrect – Sciatic nerve injury causes foot drop and weakness in knee flexion rather than a Trendelenburg gait.
